Proof Bolzano Weierstrass theorem for R1:
Suppose that S is a bounded infinite subset in â„ .
Let I = [a, b] bounds S. i.e. s ⊂ [a, b]
Let us bisects I into two parts such that, one of them contains infinitely many points of S. Let this be I1 = [a1, b1]such that b1 – a1 =
Again, Let us bisect the I1 into two parts, the one of them contains infinitely many points of S. Let this be i2 = [a2, b2] such that b2- a2 = ...
By continuing this process. We get I1, I2, I3, …, In, …
Here, each Ik contains infinitely many points of S and I1 ⊂ I2 ⊂ I3⊂.⊂In⊂ …..
Also, a1≤ a2≤a3≤…≤ an≤….≤b1 and a1≤…≤ bn≤…≤b2≤b2≤b1
This shows that {an} is bounded above by b1 and {bn) is bounded below by a1.
So, sup{an} and inf{bn} exists.
And 0≤ inf{bn} – sup{an} < → 0 as n → ∞ .
→ inf{bn}= sup{an} = x (say)
→ we can construct a ball B(x; r) of radius r >0.
For that r, we can take n so large such that In = [an, bn] ⊂ B(x; r)
→ the ball B(x; r) contains infinitely many points of S as [an, bn] does.
→ x is a limit point of S.

Let S be a subset of R^n, and x a point in R^n, x not necessarily in S. Then x is said to be adherent to S if every n-ball B(x) contains al least one point of S.

Let S be a subset of R^n, and x a point in R^n, then x is said to be an accumulation point of S if every n-ball B(x) contains al least one point of S distinct from x.

Can anybody give me an example of each definition?

S={x|x belongs to (4,5)}, then every x in S is adherent to S.
However, if S={x|x is union of {1} and (4,5)}, then 1 is not an accumulation point of S. In fact, 1 is an isolated point of S, because there exist an open ball such that it is not contained in S.

In mathematical analysis, a metric space M is called complete (or a Cauchy space) if every Cauchy sequence of points in M has a limit that is also in M or, alternatively, if every Cauchy sequence in M converges in M.

R^n is a complete metric space.

Q is not a complete metric space.
